content.question: The writer wants to add a sentence after sentence 11 to conclude the passage with a quotation that effectively restates and reinforces the overall argument. Which of the following choices best accomplishes this goal?

choices.label: In the words of literary critics David Rejeski and Robert Olson, “to be human is to ponder the future.”
According to English professor John Huntington, “If we in the present are going to think about the future in any scientific way, we have to reason from the experience of the past.”

As University of Glasgow lecturer Gavin Miller argues, “Science fiction does not invite us to be prophets, but anthropologists making sense of a complex and troubling foreign culture—which we may eventually come to recognize as our own.”

As science fiction writer Orson Scott Card puts it, novelists must imagine fantastical and sometimes terrifying possibilities, “so that if the worst does come, we’ll already know how to live in that universe.”

content.answer: As University of Glasgow lecturer Gavin Miller argues, “Science fiction does not invite us to be prophets, but anthropologists making sense of a complex and troubling foreign culture—which we may eventually come to recognize as our own.”

skill.text: Skill 2.A: Write introductions and conclusions appropriate to the purpose and context of the rhetorical situation.
